answers.author: Derek Johnson
answers.text:
Linda, 
As I am sure you are already aware, U.S. Senators Mark Udall (D-CO) and James Risch (R-ID) introduced federal legislation last year that would address this issue. 
http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/cpquery/R?cp111:FLD010:@1%28sr313%29:
However, as that legislation is currently pending and has been subject to significant compromise and revision, attached is a list of legislation that has been introduced to address this issue on a state and federal level. As most local legislation must operate within the boundaries of state and federal legislation, it may turn out that any law passed within Larimer will end up being superseded within a year or two. That possibility should be understood by any county looking to be proactive when it comes to implementing local pine beetle or dead timber removal policies.
Also, this Forest Health page lists the contacts of several local and county officials who are developing policies to remove or lessen the impact of dead or infected trees.
 There is also a page describing several examples of local action that has been taken within Colorado to address the issue, though these examples are more than a year old and may not be as useful to you. 
http://www.summitpinebeetle.org/local-action
http://www.summitpinebeetle.org/facts-a-resources/public-policy
Hope this helps!
Derek Johnson

author: Unknown
text: With all the pine beetle damage in the Rockies, has any jurisdication adopted land use regulations to allow, or even encourage, businesses that clear dead timber and process products for sale? Larimer County, Colorado is considering such a regulation and would welcome examples from others' experiences.
title: Beetle Kill Pine Products
